By virtue of growing up low-income, my siblings and I went to some of New York City's most struggling public schools. I had over 60 absences when I was in seventh grade, because I didn't feel like going to class. My high school had a 55 percent graduation rate, and even worse, only 20 percent of the kids graduating were college-ready.When I actually did make it to college, I told my friend Brennan how our teachers would always ask us to raise our hands if we were going to college. I was taken aback when Brennan said, "Karim, I've never been asked that question before." It was always, "What college are you going to?" Just the way that question is phrased made it unacceptable for him not to have gone to college.Nowadays I get asked a different question. "How were

I would like to share with you a new model of higher education, a model that, once expanded, can enhance the collective intelligence of millions of creative and motivated individuals that otherwise would be left behind. Look at the world. Pick a place and focus on it. You will find humans chasing higher education. Let's meet some of them.Patrick. Patrick was born in Liberia to a family of 20 children. During the civil war, he and his family were forced to flee to Nigeria. There, in spite of his situation, he graduated high school with nearly perfect grades. He wanted to continue to higher education, but due to his family living on the poverty line, he was soon sent to South Africa to work and send back money to feed his family. Patrick never gave up his dream of higher education. Late at night, after work, he surfed the net, looking for ways to study.Meet Debbie. Debbie is from Florida. Her parents didn't go to college, and neither did any of her siblings. Debbie has worked all her life, pays taxes, supports herself month to month, proud of the American dream, a dream that just won't be complete without higher education. But Debbie doesn't have the savings for higher education. She can't pay the tuition. Neither could she leave work.Meet Wael. Wael is from Syria. He's experiencing firsthand the misery, fear and failure imposed on his country. He's a big believer in education. He knew that if he could find an opportunity for higher education, an opportunity to get ahead of the

So I'll be talking about the success of my campus, the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, UMBC, in educating students of all types, across the arts and humanities and the science and engineering areas. What makes our story especially important is that we have learned so much from a group of students who are typically not at the top of the academic ladder — students of color, students underrepresented in selected areas. And what makes the story especially unique is that we have learned how to help African-American students, Latino students, students from low-income backgrounds, to become some of the best in the world in science and engineering.And so I begin with a story about my childhood. We all are products of our childhood experiences. It's hard for me to believe that it's been 50 years since I had the experience of being a ninth grade kid in Birmingham, Alabama, a kid who loved getting A's, a kid who loved math, who loved to read, a kid who would say to the teacher — when the teacher said, "Here are 10 problems," to the class, this little fat kid would say, "Give us 10 more." And the whole class would say, "Shut up, Freeman." And there was a designated kicker every day. And so I was always asking this question: "Well how could we get more kids to really love to learn?"And amazingly, one week in church, when I really didn't want to be there and I was in the back of the room being placated by doing math problems, I heard this man say this: "If we can get the children
output: Here’s the advice I’d give to my younger self (and others) just starting college, especially for those who’ve overcome adversity to get there:  ### **1. Your Background Is a Strength, Not a Limitation**   You’ve already beaten odds many couldn’t imagine. The resilience you’ve built from scarcity, instability, or systemic barriers? That’s your superpower. Don’t downplay it—use it. Many of your peers have never faced the challenges you’ve navigated. Your perspective is valuable.    ### **2. College Isn’t Just About Grades—It’s About Networks**   No one cares about your GPA after your first job. What matters:   - **Relationships**: Befriend professors, join clubs, attend office hours. The person sitting next to you might be your future business partner or referral.   - **Skills**: Learn to write, speak, and think critically. Take a public speaking class if nothing else.   - **Experiences**: Internships, research, or part-time jobs in your field > straight A’s with no real-world application.    ### **3. Ask for Help Early and Often**   Struggling in a class? Visit the tutoring center *now*, not after you fail the midterm. Need money for textbooks? Ask the financial aid office about emergency grants. Pride won’t pay your bills or pass your courses. Resources exist—use them.    ### **4. Debt Is a Tool, Not a Trap**   If you’re taking loans:   - **Major matters**: A $50k loan for engineering? Probably fine. The same for a degree with no clear ROI? Be cautious.   - **Work part-time**: Even 10 hours/week in a lab, library, or campus job builds résumé lines and cuts debt.   - **Apply for every scholarship**: $500 here and there adds up.    ### **5. “Rich” Isn’t Just Money—It’s Options**   You’re in college to buy yourself *choices*. A degree won’t magically make you wealthy, but it’ll open doors your parents never had. Want to be a janitor? Fine. Want to be a CEO? Now you *can*. The goal is agency.    ### **6. You’ll Feel Like an Imposter. Everyone Does.**   That kid who sounds smarter? They’re faking it too. The professor who seems intimidating? They once failed a class. College is full of people pretending they belong—until they realize they *do*.    ### **7. Time Is Your Most Valuable Asset**   - **Skip the "grind" mentality**: 4 hours of focused work > 8 hours of distracted cramming.   - **Schedule rest**: Burnout isn’t a badge of honor. Sleep. Eat. Call your mom.   - **Drop the guilt**: Taking a break isn’t laziness; it’s sustainability.    ### **8. Failure Isn’t the End—It’s Data**   Failed a test? Changed majors three times? Good. Now you know what *doesn’t* work. The only real failure is not trying because you’re afraid to mess up.    ### **9. Don’t Wait for Permission**   No one will tap you on the shoulder and

output: I'm delighted to share some books that have significantly influenced my perspective on various topics. Here are my recommendations, along with a brief description of each:  1. "Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind" by Yuval Noah Harari    - This book provides a sweeping narrative of the history of Homo sapiens, from the emergence of our species to the modern world. It challenges conventional wisdom and encourages readers to rethink their understanding of human history, culture, and identity.  2. "Thinking, Fast and Slow" by Daniel Kahneman    - Kahneman, a Nobel laureate in Economics, explores the two systems that drive the way we think: System 1, fast, intuitive thinking, and System 2, slow, deliberate thinking. This book offers insights into how our biases and heuristics shape our decisions and perceptions.  3. "Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies" by Jared Diamond    - Diamond examines the factors that have shaped the course of human history, focusing on geography, technology, and culture. This book challenges the notion of racial superiority and encourages readers to consider the complex interplay of factors that have led to the development of different societies.  4. "The Power of Now: A Guide to Spiritual Enlightenment" by Eckhart Tolle    - Tolle invites readers to live in the present moment, arguing that our suffering stems from our attachment to the past and fear of the future. This book offers practical advice for cultivating mindfulness and living a more fulfilling life.  5. "The Man Who Knew Infinity: A Life of the Genius Ramanujan" by Robert Kanigel    - This biography of the Indian mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan offers a fascinating exploration of the power of mathematical intuition and the interplay between Eastern and Western mathematics.  6. "The Gene: An Intimate History" by Siddhartha Mukherjee    - Mukherjee traces the history of genetics, from its origins to the latest breakthroughs in gene editing. This book offers a thought-provoking exploration of the ethical, social, and scientific implications of our growing understanding of the genetic basis of life.  7. "The Art of War" by Sun Tzu    - This ancient Chinese military treatise offers timeless wisdom on strategy, leadership, and decision-making. It encourages readers to think deeply about the nature of conflict and the art of winning without fighting.  8. "The Structure of Scientific Revolutions" by Thomas S. Kuhn    - Kuhn challenges the traditional view of science as a steady, linear progression of knowledge. Instead, he argues that scientific progress is characterized by periods of normal science, followed by revolutionary shifts in paradigms. This book offers a new way of understanding the nature of scientific discovery and the role of human judgment in the scientific process.  9. "The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined" by Steven Pinker    - Pinker challenges the common perception that violence is an inherent part

([Available on Archive.org](https://archive.org/))   - **"The Art of War" by Sun Tzu** – Strategy and adaptability in conflict (and life). ([Free PDFs available](https://www.gutenberg.org/))   - **"1984" by George Orwell** – A dystopian classic on surveillance and truth. ([Public domain in some countries](https://www.gutenberg.org/))    ### **For Your Mini Book Club**   - **"Atomic Habits" by James Clear** – Practical advice on habit formation.   - **"The Alchemist" by Paulo Coelho** – A philosophical novel on destiny and purpose.   - **"Man’s Search for Meaning" by Viktor Frankl** – Finding purpose in suffering.
